question: You are a coding expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to provide executable code when possible. How do I create a student roll call software?

checklist.title: Is the core roll call functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code implements the essential features for student attendance tracking: student data management (add/edit/delete), attendance status recording (present/absent/late), and date/time tracking. Score 0 if the core functionality is missing, 5 if basic attendance recording is implemented, and 10 if features include batch operations and attendance statistics.

checklist.title: Is there a proper student data management system?
checklist.description: Check whether the software includes comprehensive student data management capabilities: importing/exporting student lists, search/filter functions, and data validation. Deduct 5 points if there's no data persistence mechanism, 3 points if student information is limited to basic fields only (missing photo/ID/contact details), and 3 points if there's no bulk import option from CSV/Excel. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the software have reporting and analytics capabilities?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code includes attendance statistics and reporting: individual student attendance rates, class-wide analytics, and exportable reports (PDF/Excel). Deduct 5 points if there are no visual charts for attendance trends, 3 points if detailed filtering options are missing, and 5 points if there's no export functionality. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are there multiple attendance verification methods?
checklist.description: Check whether the software implements various attendance verification methods: manual roll call, barcode/QR code scanning, facial recognition, or automated verification. Deduct 3 points for each missing verification method beyond basic manual entry. Give 10 points if at least three methods are implemented with seamless switching between them.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as duplicate entries, network issues when saving data, invalid student IDs, etc.) and provide friendly error messages or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Automated notifications for absent students/parents 2. Integration with calendar for scheduling 3. Voice command support for faster roll calls). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple ways to add students that cause confusion) 2. Function modules unrelated to attendance tracking (e.g., a built-in game) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations that slow down the roll call process). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data models/UI/business logic layers), unit test coverage, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size â‰¥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Roll call operation completes within 1-2 seconds 2) Search/filter results update in real-time 3) Clear visual feedback for attendance status changes. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for laggy interface when handling large class sizes, and 5 points for hard-to-find key function buttons. The full score is 10 points.
